Award.AwardTitle: Support for Research Team Seminars in Anthropology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The School for Advanced Research (SAR), an advanced research center for anthropology and allied disciplines located in Santa Fe, NM, will undertake a program of Research Team Seminars. They will bring together scientists who are independently working on a particular anthropological topic and need the time, space, and seclusion that SAR provides in order to discuss, synthesize, and analyze the results of their collaborative research and develop future plans for successful completion of their projects. Eligible research teams will be those in which the primary focus is on a question of anthropological importance, but the teams may be interdisciplinary and international in scope. This award provides three years of funding to support at least two Research Team Seminars each year.

This award supports a recent trend in the scientific community towards increased collaborative, interdisciplinary, and international research, which has been found to produce products of increased quality and importance. Studies on the practice of collaborative science demonstrate that, while digital communication is an important component of team research, sustained face-to-face interaction is also needed to successfully advance the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With support of the National Science Foundation (NSF), the School for Advanced Research (SAR), an advanced research center for anthropology and allied disciplines located in Santa Fe, NM, established a successful program to promote and support interdisciplinary and international research on anthropological topics. Building upon SAR’s venerable Advanced Seminars, which bring together scholars who are independently working on a particular anthropological topic, the Research Team Seminar Program supported existing or nascent research teams who needed the time and venue to discuss, synthesize, and/or analyze the results of their collaborative research and develop future plans for successful completion of their projects. Eligible research teams were those in which the primary focus was on a question of anthropological importance, but the program was especially designed for those teams that were interdisciplinary and international in scope. 

SAR formally established the Research Team Seminar Program with NSF funding in late 2008. Originally, the three years of funding was anticipated to support two seminars each year. With one year of supplemental funding approved in 2010, the NSF funding was anticipated to be sufficient to hold a total of eight seminars. Due to careful stewardship of the grant, however, SAR was able to stretch the funding to cover 12 seminars—representing a total of 98 participating scholars—at an average cost of less than $10,000 per seminar, including domestic and international transportation, food, lodging, and modest direct salary support; no indirect costs were charged to NSF.

A total of 43 applications were received during the four years of the grant, of which 27.9% were selected. The first applications were predominantly archaeological in focus, even though the research teams consistently included scholars from multiple disciplines and nations. As the program progressed, the number of applications for team seminars focused on cultural and/or applied anthropology increased. This trend may have reflected the delayed effects of SAR’s promotion of the Research Team Seminar program and/or an increase in team research projects in cultural anthropology. Either way, the total number of applications from all disciplines steadily increased over the grant period, reflecting growing interest and value placed on the SAR Research Team Seminars.

Success of the Research Team Seminar Program is being evaluated both through feedback from the program participants as well as by tracking the publications and other outcomes from the seminars. Dr. Linda Whiteford (USF), for example, described The Role of Social Networks in Disaster Recovery in Mexico, Ecuador, and the U.S. seminar that she organized in April 2012 as a “terrific meeting... We are very pleased with the information we covered and data that got analyzed—each activity would have been much more difficult to find time to complete elsewhere.” And as Peter Siegel (Montclair), the organizer for the Pre-Columbian Caribbean research team seminar, recently exclaimed, “the seminar was enormously helpful for us in pulling together strands of data in ways that emails just can’t. The face-to-face interactions, formally and informally, were irreplaceable.” Already, three books and several article manuscripts are in various stages of publication as a result of the interactions that this program made possible.

Perhaps most importantly, the increased interest and participation in the SAR Research Team Seminar program played a significant role in encouraging collaborative science, a major goal that has been articulated by the NSF, National Academies, and National Science Board in recent years.
